awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Multiscale Simulation of Liquid-Vapor Phase Change Heat Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
Connecting microscale heat transfer and large-scale flows in boiling and condensation in energy systems

40% of US energy consumption is used as heat to boil steam for power production. 72% of this energy invested in steam production is rejected to the environment through gas-to-liquid condensation. Boiling and condensation are therefore critical processes in the energy landscape. Improved understanding of these processes can lead to increased efficiencies in power generation, refrigeration, and freshwater distillation. Boiling and condensation are governed by mechanisms that occur over a wide range of size scales, and the interplay between these scales is not yet well understand. For example, in boiling, vapor bubbles form in minute cavities on heated surfaces, grow and detach into the bulk liquid, and merge to form large gaseous structures. Flow and heat transfer effects at these three scales have been postulated to interact in a complex fashion. In this project, computational methods will be developed to predict interactions between scales in boiling and condensation. Experiments will be performed to assess and refine computational models. Resulting models and gained insights will guide engineering of enhanced energy system equipment to improve heat transfer performance and overall efficiency. In a complementary outreach effort, a new teaching module will be developed and implemented in diverse regional secondary schools, introducing energy issues and computer modeling skills. As part of this project, students will collect measurements of residential appliance energy consumption to be incorporated into a web-tool that provides guidance on appliance efficiency and environmental impacts for the public. Research on transport in energy systems will complement development and implementation of a teaching module and classroom-based research project for secondary school students in diverse regional communities introducing energy issues and computer modeling skills. Secondary school student measurements of residential appliance energy consumption will be incorporated into a public web-tool that provides estimates of efficiency and environmental impacts, and guidance on appliance age and cost tradeoffs. At the university teaching level, a new project-driven Energy Systems course will be developed in which students will develop public tutorial videos on key energy technologies.

This project seeks to characterize the coupling between micro-scale heat transfer and large-scale fluid dynamics in flow boiling and dropwise condensation through an experimentally validated multiscale simulation framework. By modeling small, dispersed features in an averaged sense, directly tracking trajectories of intermediate vapor and liquid features, and resolving large structures, this approach will capture interactions between scales, which have been understood independently. For flow boiling, this will be applied to study interactions between large vapor bubble wakes and bubble nucleation and the development of two-phase flow structures. For dropwise condensation, this approach will quantify the effects of transport properties on transient condensation and hydrodynamic contributions to heat transfer. The approach will be validated and complemented with experimental high-speed photography and thermal imaging studies. Simulation software will be released open-source to support research for applications in power generation, absorption cooling, water distillation, and electronics cooling.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to characterize the multiscale nature of flow boiling and condensation heat transfer, which represent critical processes in many energy intensive technologies. Boiling and condensation are governed by mechanisms that occur over a wide range of size scales, and the interplay between these scales is complex and highly coupled. For example, in boiling, vapor bubbles nucleate in minute cavities on heated surfaces, grow and detach into the bulk liquid, and merge to form large gaseous structures. Improved understanding of these processes can lead to increased efficiencies in power generation, refrigeration, and freshwater distillation.

A unique experimental system was developed to simultaneously capture high speed visual and thermal imaging of the interaction between large vapor bubbles and small nucleation sites on walls in flow boiling. Analysis of these data revealed interaction processes, including how wakes from such large flowing bubbles can locally enhance overall heat transfer, but also cause a quenching effect that suppresses nucleate boiling. Similarly, an experimental approach was developed to study the rapid start-up of dropwise condensation. This effort coupled millisecond resolution high-speed photography and direct surface heat transfer measurements to resolve the stages of dropwise condensation initialization for the first time. This experiment revealed a progression from initial droplet formation, to a critical avalanche phase in which droplets slide and "renew" the surface, to a cyclic steady-state condition. Computational simulation tools were developed to capture such multiscale interactions in these heat transfer processes, informed by experimental findings. This software was released open-source to support thermal sciences research and engineering.

In a complementary education and outreach effort, a classroom-based research program was developed for secondary school students introducing energy issues and computer modeling skills. In the classroom-based research program, secondary school students have the opportunity to design authentic experiments and perform measurements of household appliance energy consumption. This module was shared with regional teachers in a hands-on workshop entitled: "Is Your Refrigerator Running Efficiently?". Real-world measurements have been compiled online, and begin to illustrate how appliance energy consumption varies with factors such as equipment age and household size.

This project supported the training of two PhD students who are now applying their thermal sciences research skills professionally to advancing efficiency for building energy systems and datacenter cooling. Additionally, this grant provided research opportunities for multiple undergraduate students seeking to pursue careers in science and engineering.


Last Modified: 05/08/2024
Modified by: Alexander S Rattner

Images (1 of )
  • High speed photography of the flow boiling process with an intermittent Taylor flow pattern. The images illustrate the interaction between large Taylor bubbles and small nucleating bubbles during the heat transfer process.
    Xiang Zhang, Alexander Rattner
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alexander S Rattner
    Intermittent flow boiling
  • Illustration of a proposed approach to simulate the multi-scale interactions during dropwise condensation heat transfer
    Alexander Rattner
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alexander S Rattner
    Concept for multiscale simulation of dropwise condensation
  • High speed images of the startup process for dropwise condensation of steam at high heat fluxes. Images reveal the transition from direct condensation of individual droplets through the avalanche phase.
    Sanjay Adhikari, Alexander Rattner
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Alexander S Rattner
    Evolution of dropwise condensation heat transfer
